section.title: Introduction

sectiondiv.p: In a cloud, the controller and compute nodes have volume groups setup based on the disk templates in the input model files. The volumes in these volume groups are allocated space based on fixed percentages. These percentages are determined by the number of services running in a node and the disk space requirements for a particular service using that volume.

The recommended percentage allocations for different types of deployments are made available via the example configurations. In , new services have been added and some existing services have undergone architectural changes. As a result, the minimum disk space requirements and allocation percentages for the various volumes have changed. The disk templates in the examples folder for have been updated to accommodate this.

section.p: This means that after upgrade to , your existing disks and volume allocations that originated in will now be incompatible with the recommended values for a cloud now running services.
If you are planning on upgrading from to , this document will:

ul.li: Help you decide if you need to add new disks to the controller and compute nodes.
Help you determine whether to add new disks to an existing volume group or a new one.
Show you how to add new disks to an existing volume group.

section.p:
For an introduction to using the online Disk sizing tool, see Disk Calculator for Compute-Centric Deployments.
Unfortunately, it is currently not possible to use the online version of the tool for determining disk sizing requirements in the Upgrade scenario. You will need to download the corresponding Excel Spreadsheet and use the retention tab for calculating the extra disk space you will need after upgrade to .
